H0.text: A landslide is the natural disaster most likely to cause the most widespread damage in a coastal ecosystem.

H1.text: A tornado is likely to cause the most widespread damage in a coastal ecosystem.

H2.text: A tsunami is the natural disaster most likely to cause the most widespread damage in a coastal ecosystem.

H3.text: An earthquake is the natural disaster most likely to cause the most widespread damage in a coastal ecosystem.

A4.text: The tsunami claimed more than 123,000 lives in Sicily and Calabria and is among the deadliest natural disasters in modern Europe.

A5.text: The 1960 Valdivia earthquake (Mw 9.5), 1964 Alaska earthquake (Mw 9.2), 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake (Mw 9.2), and 2011 T≈çhoku earthquake (Mw9.0) are recent examples of powerful megathrust earthquakes that generated tsunamis (known as teletsunamis) that can cross entire oceans.

A6.text: China was also on top with the highest area affected by landslides with more than 80,000 km2, followed by Canada with 66,000 km2 (1988 Saguenay and 1946 Vancouver Island).

A7.text: more deaths in the 1906 San Francisco earthquake were caused by fire than by the earthquake itself.
